checkpoint-1.caption: Students have equivalent access to what is seen and heard

table.task: Students have a transcript for pre-recorded audio.
Students have captions for a pre-recorded video that are complete, accurate, and synchronized.
Students can listen to audio descriptions or read text alternatives for all visual-only or uncaptioned information (e.g., math problems written on a whiteboard, children laughing together).
Students do not have to rely on color alone to receive information, take an action, give a response, or see a visual element.
Students can see text clearly because there is sufficient contrast between the text color and any background color(s).

checkpoint-2.caption: Students can interact with the video and any added elements (e.g., a quiz) with their choice of device.

table.task: Students using a keyboard will be able to close any interface element that opens (e.g., a pop-up window).
Students will have enough time to complete tasks.

checkpoint-3.caption: Students can determine the language of digital text and predict how controls will work.

table.task: Students that use a screen reader can determine the language of a transcript (or other electronic document).
Students that use a screen reader can determine the language of passages in a foreign language.
Students can hover over an interactive element, or tab to it with a keyboard, without triggering an action.
